channel.title: Database on 小巷 Blog
channel.description: Recent content in Database on 小巷 Blog

item.title: Milvus Schema Detailed Guide - Field Types and Data Modeling
item.description:
Milvus Schema Learning Document

1. Understanding Schema Concept

1.1 What is Schema?

Schema is the metadata definition of a Collection, similar to table structure definition in relational databases.

Milvus Concept Relational Database Concept Description
Schema Table Schema Metadata defining data structure
Field Column Field/column definition
DataType Data Type Data types (VARCHAR, INT, FLOAT, etc.)
Primary Key Primary Key Primary key field
Vector Field - Milvus-specific vector field
Dynamic Field - Dynamic field, similar to MongoDB’s flexible Schema

1.2 Creating Schema 

from pymilvus import MilvusClient, DataType

# Create Schema
schema = client.create_schema(
    enable_dynamic_field=True  # Enable dynamic fields
)

# Compare with MySQL
# CREATE TABLE products (
#     ...
# );

2. Field Types Detailed

2.1 Field Classification 

Field Types
├── Scalar Fields
│   ├── String (VARCHAR)
│   ├── Numbers (INT8/INT16/INT32/INT64/FLOAT/DOUBLE/BOOL)
│   ├── JSON
│   ├── Arrays (ARRAY)
│   ├── Timestamp (TIMESTAMPTZ)
│   ├── Struct Arrays (ARRAY of STRUCT)
│   └── Geometry Fields (GEOMETRY)
└── Vector Fields
    ├── Dense Vectors (FLOAT_VECTOR/FLOAT16_VECTOR/BFLOAT16_VECTOR/INT8_VECTOR)
    ├── Sparse Vectors (SPARSE_FLOAT_VECTOR)
    └── Binary Vectors (BINARY_VECTOR)

3. Primary Key Fields

3.1 Primary Key Type Comparison

Data Type Description Compare with MySQL
INT64 64-bit integer, recommended Similar to BIGINT AUTO_INCREMENT
VARCHAR Variable-length string Similar to VARCHAR(n) PRIMARY KEY

3.2 Auto ID vs Manual ID

Mode Description Use Cases Compare with MySQL
Auto ID Milvus automatically generates unique identifiers Most situations AUTO_INCREMENT
Manual ID User provides unique ID ID needs to be consistent with external systems Manually insert primary key values

3.3 Primary Key Field Examples 

# Auto ID Primary Key
schema.add_field(
    field_name="product_id",
    datatype=DataType.INT64,
    is_primary=True,    # Mark as primary key
    auto_id=True        # Auto-generate ID
)

# Compare with MySQL
# product_id BIGINT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY

# Manual ID Primary Key (using string)
schema.add_field(
    field_name="sku_code",
    datatype=DataType.VARCHAR,
    max_length=50,
    is_primary=True,
    auto_id=False       # Manual ID provision
)

# Compare with MySQL
# sku_code VARCHAR(50) PRIMARY KEY

4. Scalar Fields Detailed

4.1 String Fields (VARCHAR)

Attribute Description Range Compare with MySQL
datatype Data type DataType.VARCHAR VARCHAR
max_length Maximum length 1-65535 n in VARCHAR(n)
nullable Nullable True/False NULL/NOT NULL
default_value Default value String DEFAULT ‘value’ 
# String field example
schema.add_field(
    field_name="product_name",
    datatype=DataType.VARCHAR,
    max_length=255,
    nullable=False,
    default_value="Unnamed Product"
)

# Compare with MySQL
# product_name VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL DEFAULT 'Unnamed Product'

4.2 Numeric Fields

Milvus Type Description Range Compare with MySQL
BOOL Boolean value True/False BOOLEAN
INT8 8-bit integer -128 ~ 127 TINYINT
INT16 16-bit integer -32768 ~ 32767 SMALLINT
INT32 32-bit integer -2^31 ~ 2^31-1 INT
INT64 64-bit integer -2^63 ~ 2^63-1 BIGINT
FLOAT 32-bit float - FLOAT
DOUBLE 64-bit double - DOUBLE 
# Integer field
schema.add_field(
    field_name="stock_quantity",
    datatype=DataType.INT32,
    nullable=False,
    default_value=0
)

# Float field
schema.add_field(
    field_name="product_price",
    datatype=DataType.FLOAT,
    nullable=False
)

# Boolean field
schema.add_field(
    field_name="is_available",
    datatype=DataType.BOOL,
    default_value=True
)

# Compare with MySQL
# stock_quantity INT NOT NULL DEFAULT 0,
# product_price FLOAT NOT NULL,
# is_available BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE

4.3 JSON Fields

JSON Fields vs Dynamic Fields Comparison

Feature JSON Fields Dynamic Fields Compare with MySQL
Schema Definition Must be explicitly declared Hidden field $meta JSON column vs no equivalent concept
Use Cases Structured, known data Flexible, semi-structured data JSON column vs NoSQL features
Control User controls field names and structure System automatically managed -
Query Method metadata["key"] dynamic_key or $meta["key"] JSON_EXTRACT() 
# JSON field example
schema.add_field(
    field_name="product_detail",
    datatype=DataType.JSON
)

# Insert data example
data = {
    "product_id": 1,
    "product_detail": {
        "brand": "Apple",
        "model": "iPhone 15",
        "specs": {
            "cpu": "A17 Pro",
            "ram": "8GB"
        }
    }
}

# Compare with MySQL
# product_detail JSON
# Query: SELECT JSON_EXTRACT(product_detail, '$.brand') FROM products;

JSON Indexing

JSON indexing suitable scenarios:

  1. Structured Schema with consistent, known keys
  2. Equality and range queries on specific JSON paths
  3. Need for precise control over indexed keys
  4. Efficient storage acceleration for target queries
# Create JSON index
index_params = MilvusClient.prepare_index_params()

index_params.add_index(
    field_name="product_detail",        # JSON field name
    index_type="AUTOINDEX",             # Must be AUTOINDEX or INVERTED
    index_name="idx_product_brand",     # Index name
    params={
        "json_path": 'product_detail["brand"]',  # Top-level key
        "json_cast_type": "VARCHAR"              # Data type
    }
)

# Nested key indexing
index_params.add_index(
    field_name="product_detail",
    index_type="AUTOINDEX",
    index_name="idx_product_cpu",
    params={
        "json_path": 'product_detail["specs"]["cpu"]',  # Nested key
        "json_cast_type": "VARCHAR"
    }
)

# Compare with MySQL 8.0+
# CREATE INDEX idx_product_brand ON products((JSON_EXTRACT(product_detail, '$.brand')));

JSON Shredding Optimization

JSON shredding accelerates queries by converting row-based storage to columnar storage.

Parameter Name Description Default Adjustment Suggestions
common.enabledJSONShredding Whether to enable JSON shredding false Set to true to activate feature
common.usingJSONShreddingForQuery Whether to use shredded data for acceleration true Set to false to restore when queries fail
queryNode.mmap.jsonShredding Whether to use mmap when loading true Adjust for special memory requirements
dataCoord.jsonShreddingMaxColumns Maximum shredded columns 1024 Increase when frequent keys exceed limit
dataCoord.jsonShreddingRatioThreshold Minimum occurrence rate threshold 0.3 Adjust shredding criteria 
# milvus.yaml configuration example
common:
  enabledJSONShredding: true
  usingJSONShreddingForQuery: true

queryNode:
  mmap:
    jsonShredding: true

dataCoord:
  jsonShreddingMaxColumns: 1024
  jsonShreddingRatioThreshold: 0.3

4.4 Array Fields (ARRAY) 

# String array
schema.add_field(
    field_name="product_tags",
    datatype=DataType.ARRAY,
    element_type=DataType.VARCHAR,
    max_capacity=10,           # Up to 10 elements
    max_length=50              # Each string up to 50 characters
)

# Integer array
schema.add_field(
    field_name="related_product_ids",
    datatype=DataType.ARRAY,
    element_type=DataType.INT64,
    max_capacity=20
)

# Insert data example
data = {
    "product_id": 1,
    "product_tags": ["Electronics", "Phone", "5G", "Smart"],
    "related_product_ids": [101, 102, 103]
}

# Compare with MySQL 8.0+
# product_tags JSON  -- MySQL implements with JSON arrays
# Or use association tables for many-to-many relationships

4.5 Timestamp Fields (TIMESTAMPTZ)

TIMESTAMPTZ is timezone-aware timestamp type.

Feature Description Compare with MySQL
Input Format ISO 8601 strings (with timezone) TIMESTAMP
Internal Storage UTC normalized storage Depends on time_zone setting
Comparison Operations Unified UTC usage May be affected by timezone 
# Timestamp field
schema.add_field(
    field_name="created_at",
    datatype=DataType.TIMESTAMPTZ,
    nullable=False,
    default_value="2025-01-01T00:00:00+00:00"
)

# Insert data example
data = {
    "product_id": 1,
    "created_at": "2025-05-01T23:59:59+08:00"  # Beijing time
}

# Compare with MySQL
# created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP

Timezone Management Levels

Level Parameter Scope Priority
Database timezone Default for all collections in database Lowest
Collection timezone Override database default timezone Medium
Query/Search timezone Temporary override for specific operation Highest 
# Database level timezone setting
client.alter_database_properties(
    "my_db",
    {"timezone": "Asia/Shanghai"}
)

# Collection level timezone setting (when creating collection)
client.create_collection(
    collection_name="products",
    schema=schema,
    properties={"timezone": "America/New_York"}
)

# Specify timezone temporarily during query
client.query(
    collection_name="products",
    filter="created_at > '2025-01-01T00:00:00+08:00'",
    timezone="Asia/Shanghai"
)

4.6 Struct Arrays (ARRAY of STRUCT)

Struct arrays are used to store complex nested data.

# Product reviews array example
schema.add_field(
    field_name="reviews",
    datatype=DataType.ARRAY,
    element_type=DataType.STRUCT,
    max_capacity=100,
    element_schema={
        "fields": [
            {"name": "user_id", "type": DataType.INT64},
            {"name": "rating", "type": DataType.INT32},
            {"name": "comment", "type": DataType.VARCHAR, "max_length": 500},
            {"name": "review_vector", "type": DataType.FLOAT_VECTOR, "dim": 64},
            {"name": "timestamp", "type": DataType.TIMESTAMPTZ}
        ]
    }
)

# Insert data example
data = {
    "product_id": 1,
    "reviews": [
        {
            "user_id": 1001,
            "rating": 5,
            "comment": "Very good!",
            "review_vector": [0.1, 0.2, ...],  # 64-dimensional vector
            "timestamp": "2025-05-01T10:00:00+08:00"
        },
        {
            "user_id": 1002,
            "rating": 4,
            "comment": "Pretty good",
            "review_vector": [0.3, 0.4, ...],
            "timestamp": "2025-05-02T15:30:00+08:00"
        }
    ]
}

# Compare with MySQL
# Need to create association table reviews
# CREATE TABLE reviews (
#     review_id BIGINT PRIMARY KEY,
#     product_id BIGINT,
#     user_id BIGINT,
#     rating INT,
#     comment VARCHAR(500),
#     timestamp TIMESTAMP,
#     FOREIGN KEY (product_id) REFERENCES products(product_id)
# );

4.7 Geometry Fields (GEOMETRY)

Used to store geographic location and coordinate information.

# Geometry field
schema.add_field(
    field_name="store_location",
    datatype=DataType.GEOMETRY,
    default_value="POINT(0 0)"
)

# Insert data example
data = {
    "product_id": 1,
    "store_location": "POINT(116.4074 39.9042)"  # Tiananmen Square coordinates, Beijing
}

# Compare with MySQL
# store_location POINT NOT NULL
# Or use PostGIS extension GEOMETRY type

5. Vector Fields Detailed

5.1 Vector Type Comparison

Milvus Type Description Use Cases Storage Size
FLOAT_VECTOR 32-bit float vector High-precision semantic search 4 bytes/dim
FLOAT16_VECTOR 16-bit half-precision float Deep learning, GPU computing 2 bytes/dim
BFLOAT16_VECTOR 16-bit brain float Large-scale image retrieval 2 bytes/dim
INT8_VECTOR 8-bit integer vector Quantized models, fast inference 1 byte/dim
SPARSE_FLOAT_VECTOR Sparse float vector Full-text search, term matching Variable
BINARY_VECTOR Binary vector Resource-constrained scenarios 1 bit/dim

5.2 Dense Vector Examples 

# FLOAT_VECTOR - Standard dense vector
schema.add_field(
    field_name="product_embedding",
    datatype=DataType.FLOAT_VECTOR,
    dim=128  # 128-dimensional vector
)

# FLOAT16_VECTOR - Half-precision vector
schema.add_field(
    field_name="image_embedding",
    datatype=DataType.FLOAT16_VECTOR,
    dim=512
)

# INT8_VECTOR - Quantized vector
schema.add_field(
    field_name="text_embedding_quantized",
    datatype=DataType.INT8_VECTOR,
    dim=256
)

# Insert data example
import numpy as np

data = {
    "product_id": 1,
    "product_embedding": np.random.rand(128).tolist(),  # 128-dim float vector
    "image_embedding": np.random.rand(512).astype(np.float16).tolist(),
    "text_embedding_quantized": np.random.randint(-128, 127, 256).tolist()
}

# MySQL has no equivalent type, needs to be stored as BLOB or JSON

5.3 Sparse Vector Examples 

# Sparse vector field
schema.add_field(
    field_name="keyword_vector",
    datatype=DataType.SPARSE_FLOAT_VECTOR
)

# Insert data example (sparse vector format)
data = {
    "product_id": 1,
    "keyword_vector": {
        10: 0.5,    # Index 10 value is 0.5
        25: 0.8,    # Index 25 value is 0.8
        100: 0.3    # Index 100 value is 0.3
    }
}

6. Dynamic Fields

6.1 Dynamic Field Concept

Dynamic fields allow inserting fields not defined in Schema, which are automatically stored in the hidden $meta JSON field.

# Enable dynamic fields
schema = client.create_schema(
    enable_dynamic_field=True  # Enable dynamic fields
)

# Define basic fields
schema.add_field(
    field_name="product_id",
    datatype=DataType.INT64,
    is_primary=True,
    auto_id=True
)

schema.add_field(
    field_name="product_vector",
    datatype=DataType.FLOAT_VECTOR,
    dim=128
)

# Can include undefined fields when inserting data
data = {
    "product_id": 1,
    "product_vector": [0.1, 0.2, ...],
    "name": "iPhone 15",           # Not defined in Schema
    "category": "Electronics",     # Not defined in Schema
    "price": 999.99               # Not defined in Schema
}

# Milvus internally stores as:
# {
#   "product_id": 1,
#   "product_vector": [0.1, 0.2, ...],
#   "$meta": {
#     "name": "iPhone 15",
#     "category": "Electronics",
#     "price": 999.99
#   }
# }

6.2 Supported Types for Dynamic Fields

Type Milvus DataType Compare with MongoDB
String VARCHAR String
Integer INT8, INT32, INT64 Int32, Int64
Float FLOAT, DOUBLE Double
Boolean BOOL Boolean
Array ARRAY Array
JSON Object JSON Object

6.3 Querying Dynamic Fields 

# Direct field name query
results = client.query(
    collection_name="products",
    filter='name == "iPhone 15"',  # Directly use dynamic field name
    output_fields=["product_id", "name", "category", "price"]
)

# Or query through $meta
results = client.query(
    collection_name="products",
    filter='$meta["category"] == "Electronics"',
    output_fields=["product_id", "$meta"]
)

# Compare with MongoDB
# db.products.find({"name": "iPhone 15"})

7. Complete Schema Example 

from pymilvus import MilvusClient, DataType

# Connect client
client = MilvusClient(uri="http://localhost:19530", token="root:Milvus")

# Create Schema
schema = client.create_schema(
    enable_dynamic_field=True  # Enable dynamic fields
)

# 1. Primary key field (Auto ID)
schema.add_field(
    field_name="product_id",
    datatype=DataType.INT64,
    is_primary=True,
    auto_id=True
)

# 2. String field
schema.add_field(
    field_name="product_name",
    datatype=DataType.VARCHAR,
    max_length=255
)

# 3. Numeric field
schema.add_field(
    field_name="product_price",
    datatype=DataType.FLOAT
)

# 4. JSON field
schema.add_field(
    field_name="product_detail",
    datatype=DataType.JSON
)

# 5. Array field
schema.add_field(
    field_name="product_tags",
    datatype=DataType.ARRAY,
    element_type=DataType.VARCHAR,
    max_capacity=10,
    max_length=50
)

# 6. Timestamp field
schema.add_field(
    field_name="created_at",
    datatype=DataType.TIMESTAMPTZ
)

# 7. Struct array
schema.add_field(
    field_name="reviews",
    datatype=DataType.ARRAY,
    element_type=DataType.STRUCT,
    max_capacity=100,
    element_schema={
        "fields": [
            {"name": "user_id", "type": DataType.INT64},
            {"name": "rating", "type": DataType.INT32},
            {"name": "comment", "type": DataType.VARCHAR, "max_length": 500},
            {"name": "review_vector", "type": DataType.FLOAT_VECTOR, "dim": 64}
        ]
    }
)

# 8. Geometry field
schema.add_field(
    field_name="store_location",
    datatype=DataType.GEOMETRY,
    default_value="POINT(0 0)"
)

# 9. Dense vector field
schema.add_field(
    field_name="product_embedding",
    datatype=DataType.FLOAT_VECTOR,
    dim=128
)

# 10. Sparse vector field
schema.add_field(
    field_name="keyword_vector",
    datatype=DataType.SPARSE_FLOAT_VECTOR
)

print("✅ Schema creation completed")

8. Schema vs MySQL Comparison Summary

Operation Milvus MySQL
Create Schema client.create_schema() CREATE TABLE
Add Field schema.add_field() ALTER TABLE ADD COLUMN
Primary Key Definition is_primary=True PRIMARY KEY
Auto ID auto_id=True AUTO_INCREMENT
Nullable Field nullable=True NULL
Default Value default_value=value DEFAULT value
Vector Fields FLOAT_VECTOR etc. No equivalent type
Dynamic Fields enable_dynamic_field=True None (need JSON or NoSQL)

9. Best Practices

9.1 Field Naming Conventions 

# ✅ Recommended
"product_id"
"user_name"
"created_at"

# ❌ Avoid
"Product-ID"      # Avoid hyphens
"用户名"          # Avoid non-ASCII
"field name"     # Avoid spaces

9.2 Vector Dimension Selection

Scenario Recommended Dimensions Model Examples
Text Embedding 384-768 sentence-transformers
Image Embedding 512-2048 ResNet, CLIP
Multimodal 512-1024 CLIP, ALIGN

9.3 Index Strategy 

# Create index for vector fields
index_params = MilvusClient.prepare_index_params()

# HNSW index (recommended for high-precision search)
index_params.add_index(
    field_name="product_embedding",
    index_type="HNSW",
    metric_type="COSINE",
    params={"M": 16, "efConstruction": 256}
)

# IVF_FLAT index (suitable for large-scale data)
index_params.add_index(
    field_name="image_embedding",
    index_type="IVF_FLAT",
    metric_type="L2",
    params={"nlist": 1024}
)

10. Key Points Summary

  1. Schema Flexibility: Milvus supports dynamic fields, more flexible than traditional relational databases
  2. Native Vector Support: Vector fields are first-class citizens, no extra conversion needed
  3. Rich Types: Supports JSON, arrays, structs and other complex types
  4. Timezone Awareness: TIMESTAMPTZ provides native timezone support
  5. Index Optimization: JSON shredding, vector indexing and other optimization techniques
  6. NoSQL Integration: Dynamic fields similar to MongoDB, but retain Schema constraint advantages
